title: 112_s1931
content: The "Temporary Tax Holiday and Government Reduction Act" includes provisions for extending the payroll tax holiday and implementing deficit reduction measures such as ending certain benefits for millionaires and increasing Medicare premiums for higher-income beneficiaries. It also addresses federal employee provisions. The "Buffett Rule Act of 2011" includes provisions for reducing the number of federal employees, extending the pay freeze, and reducing discretionary spending limits. It also includes a donation option to pay down the national debt. Ending Unemployment Benefits for Millionaires by adding a new chapter on Excess Unemployment Compensation to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. A tax of 100 percent is imposed on excess unemployment compensation received by a taxpayer in any taxable year. Excess unemployment compensation is defined as the amount exceeding the taxpayer's adjusted gross income over $750,000 ($1,500,000 for joint returns) divided by $250,000 ($500,000 for joint returns). The tax imposed on excess unemployment compensation is treated as a tax under subtitle A for deficiency procedures. Excess unemployment compensation received by a taxpayer is subject to a 100 percent tax, with the excess amount defined based on adjusted gross income thresholds. The Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new tax under section 5895. A clerical amendment is made to the table of chapters for subtitle E of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Chapter 56 discusses Excess Unemployment Compensation. The amendments made by this subsection apply to unemployment compensation received after December 31, 2011. Section 6 of the Food and Nutrition Act of 2008 is amended to disqualify households with assets of at least $1,000,000 from receiving Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program benefits. The Food and Nutrition Act of 2008 is amended to disqualify households with assets of at least $1,000,000 from receiving Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program benefits. Additionally, Section 5(a) is amended to include subsections (b), (d)(2), (g), and (r) of section 6. SEC. 202. Increase in Medicare Part B and D premiums for higher-income beneficiaries, with adjustments to income thresholds. SEC. 211. REDUCTION IN THE NUMBER OF FEDERAL EMPLOYEES. The amendments made by paragraph (1) apply to 2013 and subsequent years. Amendment extends freeze on inflation adjustments in Social Security Act until December 31, 2022. The section defines "agency" and "employee," requires determination of full-time employees in each agency, and limits replacement hires to one during a specified period. The section limits replacement hires in each agency to one for every three full-time employees who leave, with a waiver possible in times of war. The President can make written determinations for declaring a state of war or emergency, and must submit them to Congress. SEC. 212. EXTENSION OF PAY FREEZE FOR FEDERAL EMPLOYEES. The Continuing Appropriations Act of 2011 is amended to extend the pay freeze for federal employees until December 31, 2015, including Members of Congress and legislative branch employees. The pay freeze for federal employees, including Members of Congress and legislative branch employees, is extended until December 31, 2015. No cost of living adjustments will be given to legislative branch employees during this period. During the period from enactment of this Act until December 31, 2015, pay freeze for federal employees, including Members of Congress and legislative branch employees, will be in effect. Reduction of revised discretionary spending limits to achieve savings from federal employee provisions. Revised discretionary spending limits for fiscal years 2013 through 2021 under the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 are specified for security and nonsecurity categories. Revised discretionary spending limits for fiscal years 2015 through 2017 are set at $556 billion for security and $503 billion for nonsecurity in 2015, $567 billion for security and $512 billion for nonsecurity in 2016, and $579 billion for security and nonsecurity in 2017. For fiscal years 2018 through 2020, the revised budget authority limits are set at $592 billion for security and $534 billion for nonsecurity in 2018, $605 billion for security and $546 billion for nonsecurity in 2019, and $618 billion for security in 2020. For fiscal year 2021, the budget authority limits are set at $632 billion for security and $568 billion for nonsecurity categories. The "Buffett Rule Act of 2011" allows for donations to pay down the national debt through an amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Buffett Rule Act of 2011" allows taxpayers to donate an amount to the general fund of the Treasury to pay down the national debt when filing their tax return. "Taxpayers can donate a portion of their payment to help pay down the national debt." Taxpayers can donate a portion of their payment to help pay down the national debt. Donations made under this section will be treated as contributions to the United States and transferred to a special account to reduce the public debt. The amendments made by this section apply to returns for taxable years ending after December 31, 2011.
